title: Asymmetric Sensorineural Hearing Loss with Tinnitus and Aural Fullness
chief_complaint: I have noticed a gradual hearing loss over the past 2 years, and my right ear seems better than my left. I also have constant ringing and a feeling of fullness in my left ear, and I'm having more trouble hearing in background noise and asking for repetitions.

problem_summary.onset: Gradual deterioration over the past 2 years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Constant tinnitus (left), slight aural fullness (left), difficulty in background noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Asking for repetitions more often; difficulty hearing in noise.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to improve hearing for TV, restaurants, and grandchildren.

history.present_illness: Patient reports gradual hearing loss, worse in the left ear, with constant left-sided tinnitus and aural fullness.
history.noise_exposure_history: Long history of unprotected noise exposure from factory work and using rifles held on the right shoulder.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal 250-500 Hz, sloping to mild SNHL at 1-2k Hz, to moderately severe at 4-8k Hz. Left ear: Normal 250-500 Hz, sloping to mild SNHL at 1k Hz, to severe SNHL at 4-8k Hz. Asymmetric configuration (Left worse).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT aligns with pure tone average. Word recognition is excellent in the right ear and good (slight difficulty) in the left ear.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear pressure, ear canal volume, and static admittance bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Ipsilateral: Normal 500-2k Hz Right; Normal 500 Hz, Elevated 1k-2k Hz Left. Absent 4k Hz bilaterally. Contralateral: Absent at most frequencies except 500 Hz (probe left) and 500-1k Hz (probe right). Reflex decay normal in Right, CNT in Left.

history.otologic_history: Evaluated by Otology. MRI and ABR performed. ABR showed normal latencies. MRI showed normal internal auditory canals. Cleared for amplification.
history.noise_exposure_history: Asymmetry attributed to noise exposure (rifle shooter).

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN performed binaurally in sound field. Results indicate a moderate SNR loss, suggesting hearing aids alone may not provide sufficient benefit in noise.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.key_findings: LDLs found to be within the normal range at all frequencies tested (500, 1000, 2000, 4000 Hz).

tests.name: Self-report scale
tests.key_findings: COSI completed. Patient identified three specific needs.

numeric_results.Goal_1: Hearing my wife better in noisy restaurants
numeric_results.Goal_2: Hearing my grandchildren better than I currently do
numeric_results.Goal_3: Hearing and understanding my TV, and the volume be lower

history.prior_management: Selected bilateral ReSound LiNX 3D 9 62 RIC hearing aids and ReSound Multi Mic.

tests.name: Real-Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Performed on FONIX 8000. Verified to NAL-NL2 targets (implied by 'prescriptive real-ear insertion gain'). Inputs 50, 65, 80 dB SPL provided appropriate gain and smooth response. RESR90 did not exceed LDLs.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral, asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, sloping from normal in the low frequencies to moderately-severe (Right) and severe (Left) in the high frequencies. The asymmetry, along with left-sided tinnitus and aural fullness, necessitated a medical referral, which ruled out retrocochlear pathology via MRI and ABR. Unaided speech-in-noise testing revealed a moderate SNR loss (14 dB), indicating significant difficulty in background noise that likely requires assistive technology beyond hearing aids alone.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is uneven between ears, and you have symptoms on the left side (ringing, fullness) that required us to rule out medical issues. The MRI and ABR results were normal, which is great news.
The pattern of your hearing loss is consistent with your history of noise exposure and shooting rifles right-handed.
You have a 'moderate' difficulty hearing in noise (SNR Loss of 14 dB). Hearing aids will help, but they might not be enough in very noisy places like restaurants.
We are recommending a remote microphone (Multi Mic) to help you hear your wife in restaurants. This streams her voice directly to your hearing aids.
It is critical to protect your hearing from any future noise exposure.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 66-year-old male who has worked in factories and used firearms.
You are cooperative but frustrated by your difficulty hearing in noise.
You have specific goals: hearing the TV, your wife in restaurants, and your grandchildren.
You are relieved that the MRI/medical workup was clear but still need help with the hearing loss.
